titleStmt.title: George Parker to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG4147

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: Your Petitioner Geo Parker will state that he is sheriff of Union County and at the last term of the Union Court, one Whitmere Mitchell was in the County seat Morganfield, drinking and disorderly. Your Petitioner was attending on the court. By order of the County Judge E S Taylor arrested Mitchell and put him in Jail Some time after the arrest an attorney of the Court moved to alow the prisoner to be brought out, and be permitted to execute bond to keep the peace. This was ordered and he was brought out, but coming into the Court house he was still noisy and the Court ordered your petitioner to again carry him to jail. Your petitioner started to the door with the prisoner carrying him to Jail, when L. S. Mitchell a brother of the prisoner when out of doors requested your petitioner to return and obtain the Judges consent that he might take him home. Your petitioner returned to ask permission of the Court to suffer his brother to take him home, the Judge refused this permission and directed me to put him in jail. I at once returned and sought out the prisoner and he had escaped and gone home ^and supposed^ when without the knowledge of your petitioner Saml C Hughes our County Judge imposed a fine on your petitioner of twenty dollars. Your petitioner
was at the time very unwell and acted in good faith and did not refuse to execute the orders of the court with any disresppect or per any favor towards the prisoner.
Wherefore he the executive to remit said fine --

A. P. Mitchell and L S Mitchell say they have read the foregoing petition and asent to the statements and say they regret Geo Parker of any blame and further that on the day of the Parker was very unwell or appeared to be

L S Mitchell
A. P. Mitchell
Sworn to before me by Geo Parker A P Mitchell & L S Mitchell this 18th September 1863

David C James
Clerk Union Circuit Court
